Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 767, 560]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 644, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 751, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 777, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 437, 136]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 1.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 152, 834, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 555, 532, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 144, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 585, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{AB}\) 4 cm from the edge of the ray-trace sheet and in the middle of the paper, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 616, 625, 635]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) parallel to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) and 10 cm from it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 632, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\) in the centre of line \(\mathbf{AB}\). Point \(\mathbf{N}\) must be an equal distance from the top and bottom of the sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 664, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
Extend the normal to line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and label the point at which it crosses line \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 146, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 725, 784, 744]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{EF}\), through point \(\mathbf{N}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1 and at an angle \(\theta = 5^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 756, 144, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 756, 834, 774]]<|/det|>
Place the plane mirror on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) with the reflecting surface facing to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 771, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
Place the screen with a slit on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and arrange the lamp so a ray of light shines along line \(\mathbf{LN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 802, 920, 834]]<|/det|>
Mark the ray that is reflected from the mirror, using a small cross at a suitable distance from point \(\mathbf{N}\). Label this cross \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 833, 702, 850]]<|/det|>
Remove the mirror, screen and lamp from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 848, 920, 867]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate how the use of a lid or insulation affects the rate of cooling of hot water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 138]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[69, 149, 928, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 359, 532, 378]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 146, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 740, 410]]<|/det|> The thermometer must remain in the clamp throughout the experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 178, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 777, 440]]<|/det|> Use the measuring cylinder to pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 188, 456]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 438, 591, 456]]<|/det|> Place the thermometer in the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 453, 170, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 453, 920, 485]]<|/det|> In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 483, 173, 502]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 483, 920, 515]]<|/det|> Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 514, 173, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 514, 547, 532]]<|/det|> Remove the thermometer from the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 917, 532]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 144, 564]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 545, 180, 564]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 545, 920, 578]]<|/det|> Repeat (a) for beaker \(\mathbf{B}\). Ensure that the lid is removed before pouring the hot water into the beaker. Replace the lid immediately after pouring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 917, 581]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 592, 180, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 592, 660, 610]]<|/det|> Complete the headings and the time column in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 592, 917, 610]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 622, 539, 640]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 650, 734, 910]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation or the lid is more effective in reducing the cooling rate of the water in the beakers in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 552, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 581, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 576, 137]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 912, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 821, 90]]<|/det|>
A student wants to investigate the effect of air resistance on the swing of a pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how air resistance changes the way in which a pendulum swings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 522, 167]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 400, 198]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
a light wooden rod, approximately \(80\mathrm{cm}\) long with a hole at one end, through which a nail will fit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 751, 260]]<|/det|>
a piece of modelling clay to act as a pendulum bob, as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 856, 274]]<|/det|>
a sheet of thick card which will provide the air resistance when the pendulum swings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 324, 306]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 138, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 457, 337]]<|/det|>
list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 134, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the experiment including exactly which measurements should be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 136, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 532, 415]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 134, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 134, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 685, 494]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 816, 524]]<|/det|>
You may add to Fig. 4.1 or draw an additional diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 536, 586, 769]]<|/det|>
